quote: We have evaluated UNet++ in comparison with U-Net and wide U-Net architectures across multiple medical image segmentation tasks.
To address the need for more accurate segmentation in medical images, we present UNet++, a new segmentation architecture based on nested and dense skip connections.
The hypothesis is that the optimizer would face an easier optimization problem when the received encoder feature maps and the corresponding decoder feature maps are semantically similar.
UNet++ with deep supervision exhibits average improvement of 0.6 points over UNet++ without deep supervision.
The suggested architecture takes advantage of re-designed skip pathways and deep supervision.
We evaluated UNet++ using four medical imaging datasets covering lung nodule segmentation, colon polyp segmentation, cell nuclei segmentation, and liver segmentation.
Our experiments demonstrated that UNet++ with deep supervision achieved an average IoU gain of 3.9 and 3.4 points over U-Net and wide U-Net, respectively.
Deep supervision also enables more accurate segmentation particularly for lesions that appear at multiple scales such as polyps in colonoscopy videos.
U-net: Convolutional networks for biomedical image segmentation.
